name: flawfinder
description:
C/C++ 安全扫描工具
Flawfinder is a simple program that scans C/C++ source code and reports potential security flaws.

checkrule_set.rule_title: This usually indicates a security flaw.  If an attacker can change anything along the path between the call to access() and the file's actual use (e.g., by moving files), the attacker can exploit the race condition (CWE-362/CWE-367!)
checkrule_set.solution: Set up the correct permissions (e.g., using setuid()) and try to open the file directly
checkrule_set.description: This usually indicates a security flaw.  If an attacker can change anything along the path between the call to access() and the file's actual use (e.g., by moving files), the attacker can exploit the race condition (CWE-362/CWE-367!)

checkrule_set.rule_title: This doesn't set the inheritance bits in the access control entry (ACE) header (CWE-732)
checkrule_set.solution: Make sure that you set inheritance by hand if you wish it to inherit
checkrule_set.description: This doesn't set the inheritance bits in the access control entry (ACE) header (CWE-732)

checkrule_set.rule_title: Unless checked, the resulting number can exceed the expected range (CWE-190)
checkrule_set.solution: If source untrusted, check both minimum and maximum, even if the input had no minus sign (large numbers can roll over into negative number; consider saving to an unsigned value if that is intended)
checkrule_set.description: Unless checked, the resulting number can exceed the expected range (CWE-190)

checkrule_set.rule_title: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination (CWE-120)
checkrule_set.solution: Make sure destination can always hold the source data
checkrule_set.description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination (CWE-120)

checkrule_set.rule_title: Statically-sized arrays can be improperly restricted, leading to potential overflows or other issues (CWE-119!/CWE-120)
checkrule_set.solution: Perform bounds checking, use functions that limit length, or ensure that the size is larger than the maximum possible length
checkrule_set.description: Statically-sized arrays can be improperly restricted, leading to potential overflows or other issues (CWE-119!/CWE-120)

checkrule_set.rule_title: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results. (CWE-362)
checkrule_set.solution: Use fchgrp( ) instead
checkrule_set.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results. (CWE-362)

checkrule_set.rule_title: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results. (CWE-362)
checkrule_set.solution: Use fchmod( ) instead
checkrule_set.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results. (CWE-362)

checkrule_set.rule_title: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results. (CWE-362)
checkrule_set.solution: Use fchown( ) instead
checkrule_set.description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results. (CWE-362)

checkrule_set.rule_title: chroot can be very helpful, but is hard to use correctly (CWE-250, CWE-22)
checkrule_set.solution: Make sure the program immediately chdir("/"), closes file descriptors, and drops root privileges, and that all necessary files (and no more!) are in the new root
checkrule_set.description: chroot can be very helpful, but is hard to use correctly (CWE-250, CWE-22)

checkrule_set.rule_title: If this call fails, the program could fail to drop heightened privileges (CWE-250)
checkrule_set.solution: Make sure the return value is checked, and do not continue if a failure is reported
checkrule_set.description: If this call fails, the program could fail to drop heightened privileges (CWE-250)

checkrule_set.rule_title: This causes a new process to execute and is difficult to use safely (CWE-78)
checkrule_set.solution: Specify the application path in the first argument, NOT as part of the second, or embedded spaces could allow an attacker to force a different program to run

checkrule_set.rule_title: The crypt functions use a poor one-way hashing algorithm; since they only accept passwords of 8 characters or fewer and only a two-byte salt, they are excessively vulnerable to dictionary attacks given today's faster computing equipment (CWE-327)
checkrule_set.solution: Use a different algorithm, such as SHA-256, with a larger, non-repeating salt
checkrule_set.description: The crypt functions use a poor one-way hashing algorithm; since they only accept passwords of 8 characters or fewer and only a two-byte salt, they are excessively vulnerable to dictionary attacks given today's faster computing equipment (CWE-327)

checkrule_set.rule_title: Environment variables are untrustable input if they can be set by an attacker.  They can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once (CWE-807, CWE-20)
checkrule_set.solution: Check environment variables carefully before using them
checkrule_set.description: Environment variables are untrustable input if they can be set by an attacker.  They can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once (CWE-807, CWE-20)

checkrule_set.rule_title: Exactly what cuserid() does is poorly defined (e.g., some systems use the effective uid, like Linux, while others like System V use the real uid). Thus, you can't trust what it does. It's certainly not portable (The cuserid function was included in the 1988 version of POSIX, but removed from the 1990 version).  Also, if passed a non-null parameter, there's a risk of a buffer overflow if the passed-in buffer is not at least L_cuserid characters long (CWE-120)
checkrule_set.solution: Use getpwuid(geteuid()) and extract the desired information instead
checkrule_set.description: Exactly what cuserid() does is poorly defined (e.g., some systems use the effective uid, like Linux, while others like System V use the real uid). Thus, you can't trust what it does. It's certainly not portable (The cuserid function was included in the 1988 version of POSIX, but removed from the 1990 version).  Also, if passed a non-null parameter, there's a risk of a buffer overflow if the passed-in buffer is not at least L_cuserid characters long (CWE-120)

checkrule_set.rule_title: It's often easy to fool getlogin.  Sometimes it does not work at all, because some program messed up the utmp file.  Often, it gives only the first 8 characters of the login name. The user currently logged in on the controlling tty of our program need not be the user who started it.  Avoid getlogin() for security-related purposes (CWE-807)
checkrule_set.solution: Use getpwuid(geteuid()) and extract the desired information instead
checkrule_set.description: It's often easy to fool getlogin.  Sometimes it does not work at all, because some program messed up the utmp file.  Often, it gives only the first 8 characters of the login name. The user currently logged in on the controlling tty of our program need not be the user who started it.  Avoid getlogin() for security-related purposes (CWE-807)

checkrule_set.rule_title: This function is obsolete and not portable. It was in SUSv2 but removed by POSIX.2.  What it does exactly varies considerably between systems, particularly in where its prompt is displayed and where it gets its data (e.g., /dev/tty, stdin, stderr, etc.). In addition, some implementations overflow buffers. (CWE-676, CWE-120, CWE-20)
checkrule_set.solution: Make the specific calls to do exactly what you want.  If you continue to use it, or write your own, be sure to zero the password as soon as possible to avoid leaving the cleartext password visible in the process' address space
checkrule_set.description: This function is obsolete and not portable. It was in SUSv2 but removed by POSIX.2.  What it does exactly varies considerably between systems, particularly in where its prompt is displayed and where it gets its data (e.g., /dev/tty, stdin, stderr, etc.). In addition, some implementations overflow buffers. (CWE-676, CWE-120, CWE-20)

checkrule_set.rule_title: This function is dangerous; it may overflow the provided buffer. It extracts data from a 'protected' area, but most systems have many commands to let users modify the protected area, and it's not always clear what their limits are.  Best to avoid using this function altogether (CWE-676, CWE-120)
checkrule_set.solution: Use getpwuid() instead
